feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 5 at 1:33PM CDT until April 5 at 10:00PM CDT by NWS Lubbock TX
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IS ALSO IN EFFECT FROM NOON SATURDAY TO MIDNIGHT CDT SATURDAY NIGHT FOR STRONG WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR ALL OF THE SOUTH PLAINS AND THE FAR SOUTHERN TEXAS PANHANDLE...
A Red Flag Warning remains in effect until 10 PM CDT this evening.
The National Weather Service in Lubbock has issued a Red Flag Warning, which is in effect from noon Saturday to midnight CDT Saturday night. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* Timing...For Today: Until 10 PM. For Saturday: Noon to midnight.
* Wind...For Today: South at 20 to 25 mph with gusts to 35 mph. For Saturday: West at 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 50 mph.
* Humidity...10 to 15 percent.
* Fuels...Dry.
* Impacts...Any fires that develop can spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is discouraged.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Parmer; Castro; Swisher; Bailey; Lamb; Hale; Cochran; Hockley; Lubbock; Yoakum; Terry; Lynn

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued April 5 at 2:30PM EDT until April 6 at 9:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures in the mid-30s, under clear skies and diminishing winds, will result in frost formation early Saturday morning.
* WHERE...Portions of northeast Georgia, piedmont and western North Carolina, and upstate South Carolina.
* WHEN...From 2 AM to 9 AM EDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued April 5 at 2:30PM EDT until April 6 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 31 are expected.
* WHERE...Rabun County.
* WHEN...From 8 PM this evening to 10 AM EDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...This replaces the Frost Advisory. Temperatures are now expected to dip below freezing across much of the county.

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 5 at 12:25PM MDT until April 5 at 4:00PM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...South winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 55 mph, with isolated areas gusting above 60 mph.
* WHERE...Eastern Juab/Millard Counties, Western Millard and Juab Counties, Great Salt Lake Desert and Mountains, Tooele and Rush Valleys, and Southwest Utah.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM MDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Cross-winds on east-west roads, particularly I-80. Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Isolated sections of I-80 where terrain enhances winds will see strong gusts over 60 mph, especially at the leading edge of precipitation associated with a cold front moving west to east.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Great Salt Lake Desert and Mountains; Tooele and Rush Valleys; Western Millard and Juab Counties; Eastern Juab/Millard Counties; Southwest Utah

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 5 at 11:24AM PDT by NWS Hanford CA
entry.summary:
At 1123 AM PDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Arvin, or 14 miles southeast of Bakersfield, moving east at 15 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Arvin, Stallion Springs, Keene, and Bear Valley Springs.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South End San Joaquin Valley; Piute Walker Basin; Tehachapi

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT SOUTHERN KERN COUNTY THROUGH NOON PDT

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued April 5 at 2:23PM EDT until April 5 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level in low lying areas due to tidal flooding.
* WHERE...Shoreline in the City of Alexandria and Arlington County.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM EDT this evening, especially around the time of high tide.
* IMPACTS...Water is expected to approach the curb near the intersection of King Street and Strand Street in Alexandria..

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 5 at 2:20PM EDT until April 6 at 6:35PM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Ohio... West Virginia...
Ohio River At Marietta Pumphouse affecting Wood, Pleasants and Washington Counties.
For the Ohio River...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Marietta Pumphouse.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 38.0 feet, Elmwood Avenue at Ash, Hart, Pike and Charles Streets at Seventh Street, Church at Second Street, Butler at Fifth Street, Ohio Street at Second and Third Streets are all flooded. At 39.0 feet, Pike street at Lafayette, Greene at Third Street, Jefferson Street at East Eight Street, Third Street between Butler and Church Streets, and Second Street at Wooster Street are all flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:00 PM EDT Friday the stage was 39.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 2:00 PM EDT Friday was 40.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 24.3 feet Wednesday morning. - Flood stage is 35.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 40.0 feet on 02/27/1979. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 5 at 12:10PM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Air Quality Health Advisory for Blowing Dust.
WHERE...Saguache, Alamosa, Rio Grande, Costilla, Conejos, Archuleta, Hinsdale, Mineral, San Juan, La Plata, Montezuma, Dolores, San Miguel, Ouray and Montrose counties. Locations include, but are not limited to, Saguache, Alamosa, Del Norte, San Luis, Conejos, Pagosa Springs, Creede, Lake City, Durango, Silverton, Cortez, Dove Creek, Telluride, Ouray, and Montrose.
WHEN...1200 PM Friday April 05 to 900 PM Friday April 05
IMPACTS...Strong and gusty winds will produce widespread areas of blowing dust on Friday. Areas of dust should gradually decrease throughout the advisory area Friday evening.
HEALTH INFORMATION...Public Health Recommendations: Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms in sensitive individuals, aggravation of heart or lung disease and premature mortality in people with cardiopulmonary disease and older adults. People with heart or lung disease, older adults, and children should reduce prolonged or heavy exertion.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mineral, CO; Alamosa, CO; Saguache, CO; Rio Grande, CO; Costilla, CO; Conejos, CO

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY HEALTH ADVISORY FOR BLOWING DUST FROM 1200 PM FRIDAY UNTIL 900 PM FRIDAY

* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 8 inches. Winds gusting as high as 75 mph.
* WHERE...Western Mosquito Range and Eastern Sawatch Mountains Above 11000 Feet.
* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to midnight MDT Saturday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Widespread blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Very strong winds could cause extensive tree damage. The cold wind chills as low as 25 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Mosquito Range/East Lake County Above 11000 Ft; Eastern Sawatch Mountains above 11000 Ft

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 5 at 1:07PM CDT by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Illinois...
Rock River near Joslin affecting Rock Island, Whiteside and Henry IL Counties.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring.
* WHERE...Rock River near Joslin.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Water affects residences in outlying areas immediately along the river including basements, yards, driveways, and access roads.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:45 AM CDT Friday the stage was 14.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:45 AM CDT Friday was 14.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 14.5 feet tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Henry, IL; Rock Island, IL; Whiteside, IL

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 5 at 2:05PM EDT until April 6 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor flooding caused by upstream Vanceboro dam release is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of DownEast Maine, including the following county, Washington.
* WHEN...Until 200 AM EDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding is occurring of low lying properties on Salmon Brook Road in Vanceboro. Possible minor flooding at camps along the St. Croix River on Loon Bay Road in Lambert Lake Township and Dyer Township. Additional minor flooding in rural areas of Eastern Washington County above the Grand Falls Flowage is expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 203 PM EDT, an upstream floodgate release at Vanceboro is expected to continue to cause minor flooding in the advisory area. - As of 1:45PM EDT the flow being released from the Vanceboro Dam is 5958 cfs. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Vanceboro, Dyer Township, Fowler Township, Dyer and Lambert Lake. - For flood safety visit http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Washington, ME

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 5 at 12:10PM CDT until April 6 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Sioux Falls SD
entry.summary:
* AFFECTED AREA...In Iowa, Lyon, Sioux, O'Brien, Plymouth, Cherokee, Woodbury and Ida. In Minnesota, Pipestone and Rock. In Nebraska, Dixon and Dakota. In South Dakota, Beadle, Kingsbury, Brookings, Sanborn, Miner, Lake, Moody, Davison, Hanson, McCook, Minnehaha, Hutchinson, Turner, Lincoln, Bon Homme, Yankton, Clay and Union.
* WINDS...Southeast 30 to 35 mph with gusts up to 55 mph.

entry.summary:
Northwesterly winds will gust between 20 and 30 mph today, and with low relative humidity near 30 percent and dry fuels, increased fire danger will result across most of the northwest Piedmont through 8 PM this evening.
Refer to your local burn-permitting authority on whether you may burn. If you do burn, exercise extreme caution.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 5 at 10:38AM CDT until April 5 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR WESTERN AND MUCH OF CENTRAL NORTH DAKOTA THIS AFTERNOON INTO THIS EVENING...
.Critical fire weather conditions are expected this afternoon into this evening across western and much of central North Dakota. Minimum relative humidity is expected to drop into the 18 to 25 percent range in central North Dakota, and 25 to 30 percent in western North Dakota. Southeast winds will be sustained from 25 to 35 mph, with gusts to 50 mph.
* WINDS...Southeast 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 18 percent.
* AFFECTED AREA...Western and much of central North Dakota.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite will spread rapidly and become difficult to control or suppress.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 5 at 10:56AM EDT until April 8 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
Ohio River At Pittsburgh affecting Allegheny County.
.The crest of the flood had moved well downstream from Pittsburgh allowing river stages to slowly fall. The Ohio River at the Point in Pittsburgh is forecast to remain above action stage affecting the Monongahela River Parking wharf into Monday.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Pittsburgh.
* WHEN...Until early Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the Monongahela Parking Wharf. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the North Shore riverwalk between the stadiums. At 19.5 feet, The Monongahela Parking Wharf is completely flooded. At 20.0 feet, Water is up to one foot deep in the lower areas of the North Shore Riverwalk. At 22.0 feet, The Tenth Street Bypass floods. At 22.5 feet, The fountain plaza is flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Friday the stage was 21.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 18.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 18.0 feet early Monday morning. - Action stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood stage is 25.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 5 at 10:40AM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
entry.summary:
Sustained winds of 10 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 25 mph are expected across the North Carolina piedmont this afternoon into early evening. Meanwhile, minimum relative humidity values around 30 percent are expected. These conditions combined with dry vegetation will enhance the potential for the start and spread of wildfires across the area.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. If you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these condition.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rockingham; Caswell

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER THIS AFTERNOON INTO EARLY EVENING

* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Overflowing of poor drainage and low lying areas will result in minor flooding along wills creek. At 16.0 feet, Basement flooding begins through floor drains and other sewer connections. Local interruptions in sanitary service may occur along Gordon's Run from 3rd Street to 6th Street. At 17.0 feet, Water overflows wills Creek Valley Road to a depth of 2 feet. Water reaches a depth of 1 foot on North Eighth Street. At 18.0 feet, Flood waters begin effecting apartments along Wills Creek Valley Road. Southgate Parkway will also begin flooding near Woodlawn Avenue. At 20.0 feet, Flood waters reach residential areas on the west side of Cambridge. At 22.0 feet, The North 8th Street Bridge near the school campus is impassable. Flood waters reach Wills Creek Valley Drive near the County Road 35 Bridge. The north side of Cambridge is close to being cut off from access. Water from Wills Creek will flood the west end of Cambridge.

entry.summary:
...DANGEROUS FIRE WEATHER POSSIBLE BEHIND DRYLINE SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING...
The National Weather Service in Hastings has issued a Fire Weather Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* WINDS...South 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 55 mph, switching to southwest then west.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Rapid decrease into the teens and low 20s percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite may spread rapidly. Use caution if engaging in activities that may result in a fire starting.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 5 at 7:36AM MDT until April 5 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT 11 AM TO 9 PM FRIDAY FOR THE NORTHWEST PLATEAU, RIO GRANDE VALLEY, SANDIA AND MANZANO MOUNTAINS BELOW SNOWPACK AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE...
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING FOR THE MIDDLE RIO GRANDE VALLEY AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Widespread critical fire weather conditions are expected on Friday as winds increase ahead of an approaching storm system. These strong winds combined with low humidity will allow for rapid fire spread in dry and receptive fuels. Strong south to southwest winds will peak during the afternoon hours, but will remain elevated through the evening and overnight Friday night. A strong cold front will surge from west to east early Saturday. Very strong westerly winds will develop behind the front and with continued low humidity values, critical fire weather conditions are expected once again on Saturday for the Rio Grande Valley and all of eastern New Mexico.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes the Middle Rio Grande Valley (Zone 106), and all of eastern New Mexico (Zones 104, 123, 125, and 126) from late Friday morning through Friday evening and again Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...On Friday, south to southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts between 45 and 50 mph. On Saturday, west 35 to 45 mph with gusts to 65 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 8 and 15 percent each day.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Plains; Middle Rio Grande Valley; Northeast Highlands; Central Highlands; East Central Plains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM THIS MORNING TO 9 PM MDT THIS EVENING... ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TO 8 PM MDT SATURDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 5 at 9:15AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Gilchrist, Columbia and Suwannee Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 915 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Friday the stage was 17.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 18.2 feet Tuesday morning. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 5 at 3:09AM HST until April 5 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...WIND ADVISORY FOR PORTIONS OF ALL ISLANDS THROUGH THIS AFTERNOON... ...HIGH WIND WARNING FOR LEEWARD KOHALA ON THE BIG ISLAND THROUGH THIS AFTERNOON...
.A strong high pressure system to the north of the islands, combined with a trough to the northwest, is producing strong and gusty trade winds. These strong winds are expected to continue though this afternoon and possibly extended into Saturday at Wind Advisory levels for some areas.
* WHAT...East winds 20 to 35 mph with localized gusts over 50 mph.
* WHERE...Winds will be strongest through mountain saddles, over ridges and downslope of mountains. Some areas particularly prone to these gusty winds will be the Waimea and Kohala areas of the Big Island, West Maui and the higher elevations of Lanai.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Winds this strong can tear off shingles, knock down tree branches, blow away tents and awnings and make it difficult to steer, especially for drivers of high profile vehicles.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kauai Southwest; Kauai Mountains; Waianae Coast; Oahu North Shore; Olomana; Central Oahu; Waianae Mountains; Lanai Mauka; Kahoolawe; Maui Windward West; Maui Leeward West; Kauai North; Kauai East; Kauai South; East Honolulu; Honolulu Metro; Ewa Plain; Koolau Windward; Koolau Leeward; Molokai Windward; Molokai Southeast; Molokai North; Molokai West; Molokai Leeward South; Lanai Windward; Lanai Leeward; Lanai South; Maui Central Valley North; Maui Central Valley South; Windward Haleakala; South Haleakala; Big Island South; Big Island Southeast; Big Island North

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 5 at 3:40AM MDT until April 6 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
entry.summary:
...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS WILL DEVELOP SATURDAY AFTERNOON...
.A combination of increasing west/northwest winds behind a passing cold front, low relative humidity, and continued drying of fine fuels will potentially produce critical fire weather conditions across portions of south-central New Mexico and far west Texas on Saturday. Fuel moisture is dry enough along the desert lowlands to pose a risk of wildfire starts.
The National Weather Service in El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa has issued a Red Flag Warning, which is in effect from noon to 8 PM MDT Saturday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* TIMING...Beginning late Saturday morning into early Saturday evening.
* WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Highs in the upper 50s to lower 60s.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Lowlands And Southern Rio Grande Valley; El Paso; Hudspeth

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 5 at 3:13AM MDT until April 7 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 8 to 16 inches, with locally up to 24 inches in the upper Cottonwoods.
* WHERE...Wasatch Mountains I-80 North, Wasatch Mountains South of I-80 and Western Uinta Mountains.
* WHEN...From noon today to midnight MDT Saturday night.
* IMPACTS...Winter driving conditions can be expected late this afternoon, then again late tonight throughout much of the day Saturday.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A cold front will bring a band of moderate to heavy snow this afternoon across the area, with snowfall rates in excess of 1 inch per hour likely between 2 PM and 6 PM. Behind the front, a break in snow is expected this evening, before the second portion of the storm system impacts the area late tonight through Saturday. Widespread snowfall, heavy at times, can be expected across the area much of Saturday before tapering off late in the evening.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wasatch Mountains I-80 North; Wasatch Mountains South of I-80; Western Uinta Mountains

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM NOON TODAY TO MIDNIGHT MDT SATURDAY NIGHT

Behind the front, a break in snow is expected this evening, before the second portion of the storm system impacts the area late tonight through Saturday. Elsewhere, periods of snow can be expected throughout the day Saturday.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 11:59PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
A band of steady snow has developed over Anchorage this evening and is expected to persist through much of the day on Friday. Snowfall may gradually taper off as early as Friday morning on the west side of town, but will likely persist well into Friday afternoon across East Anchorage.
Additional snowfall accumulation through Friday afternoon of 2 to 5 inches is expected, with higher amounts up to 9 inches possible across the Anchorage Hillside. Expect difficult travel conditions across Anchorage where heavier snowfall persists, especially during the Friday morning commute and towards the east side of town.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anchorage

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued April 5 at 1:17AM MDT until April 7 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
* WHAT...South winds at 30 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph possible this evening through Saturday morning, shifting to the west Saturday afternoon. West to northwest winds at 30 to 50 mph with gusts up to 70 mph possible Saturday night into Sunday.
* WHERE...Entire Tri-State area.
* WHEN...This evening through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous travel conditions are likely over much, or all, of the Tri-state area this weekend. High winds may also move loose debris, damage property and cause power outages.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Southerly winds will rapidly shift to the west as a cold front sweeps eastward across the area late Saturday morning and Saturday afternoon. Strong west to northwest winds will follow, in the wake of the front. The abrupt nature of the wind shift may catch motorists off guard. Widespread, significant reductions in visibility associated with blowing dust are possible during the frontal passage. A prolonged period of strong, perhaps damaging, west to northwest winds are possible Saturday evening into the day on Sunday.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 4 at 6:10PM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has extended an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect through tomorrow night.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation Slow down if driving on dirt roads Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chuckwalla Mountains; Chiriaco Summit; Chuckwalla Valley

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT DUE TO ELEVATED PARTICLE POLLUTION LEVELS FROM WINDBLOWN DUST

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued April 4 at 5:20PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVWGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche warning. This avalanche warning does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 2 to 3 ft of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions. Travel in or near avalanche terrain is not recommended.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected wind drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Thu 04:00 EDT to Fri 04:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS...Natural and human-triggered avalanches that are large enough to bury multiple people, snap trees, and destroy structures are very likely to occur. These large avalanches may run far down their historic paths into the areas that are typically considered safe zones.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Coos

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 4 at 3:58PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Friday, April 5, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Friday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone: Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland Harris; Inland Brazoria; Inland Galveston; Coastal Harris; Coastal Brazoria; Coastal Galveston; Brazoria Islands; Galveston Island; Bolivar Peninsula

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued April 2 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVAGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche watch. This avalanche watch does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 30+ inches of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including but not limited to Tuckerman Ravine, Huntington Ravine, Gulf of Slides, Great Gulf, King Ravine, Burt Ravine, Ammonoosuc Ravine, Oakes Gulf and steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside of the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 16:00 EDT to Fri 16:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS... Large, destructive avalanches are likely to occur naturally and spontaneously and will exist throughout steep terrain including hiking trails. These avalanches may be large enough to bury multiple people, do significant damage to trees or buildings, and will likely run far down in paths or areas that are normally safe zones. Precipitation rates are forecast to be heavy, with 1-2 inches of snow falling per hour at times and visibility limited.
